abstract.p: Robert Goodman letter imagines benefits if US military experts could shift from 'wasteful' arms programs to more socially useful projects

block.p: Re ''U.S. to Steer Ex-Arms Experts to Peaceful Jobs'' (news article, Dec. 19):

I'd like to see our military scientists given the same job option that the State Department just announced for Iraq's 600 former weapons experts. This sensible program will spend millions on energy, environmental protection and other research, so that the Iraqi experts won't be tempted to go work for terrorists or rogue regimes.
Re ''U.S. to Steer Ex-Arms Experts to Peaceful Jobs'' (news article, Dec. 19):

I'd like to see our military scientists given the same job option that the State Department just announced for Iraq's 600 former weapons experts. This sensible program will spend millions on energy, environmental protection and other research, so that the Iraqi experts won't be tempted to go work for terrorists or rogue regimes.

Imagine the innovations in renewable energy, high-speed rail or disease control that could result if many of our own military experts were able to shift from wasteful multibillion-dollar missile defense systems, for example, and be paid to work on more socially useful projects.
The writer is a professor of environmental design, Hampshire College.
